title: 108_hr1800
content: The policy of the United States is to end animal suffering caused by steel-jawed leghold traps by prohibiting their import, export, and interstate shipment, along with fur from animals trapped in such traps. Prohibited acts and penalties are outlined in the legislation. The legislation prohibits importing, exporting, or transporting fur or steel-jawed leghold traps in interstate commerce. It also prohibits selling or acquiring traps in violation of the law and violating any rules set by the Secretary. Penalties include imprisonment or fines for violations. The legislation offers rewards for providing information leading to convictions under the Act, with exceptions for government officials. Enforcement measures are outlined in Section 4. The Act is enforced by the Secretary, who can use personnel and facilities from other agencies. Import and export violations are treated as customs law violations. Enforcement authorities can act on violations, except for those under import and export violations. Enforcement authorities can detain, search, and seize packages suspected of containing articles in violation of the Act. They can also make arrests without a warrant for violations committed in their presence or with probable cause. Enforcement authorities have the power to make arrests without a warrant for violations of the Act committed in their presence or with probable cause. They can also execute and serve arrest warrants, search warrants, or other criminal process issued by a judge or magistrate for enforcement of the Act. Additionally, any article of fur or conventional steel-jawed leghold trap involved in violations of the Act may be subject to forfeiture. Any article of fur or conventional steel-jawed leghold trap involved in violations of the Act may be subject to forfeiture under the customs laws of the United States. Provisions for seizure, forfeiture, disposition of property, remission, and compromise of claims apply to such forfeitures. The Act allows for the remission, mitigation, and compromise of forfeitures incurred under its provisions. Enforcement duties can be carried out by the Secretary or designated officers. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators, and cooperation is required from the Secretaries of Commerce and the Treasury. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators of the Act, and cooperation is required from relevant agencies for effective enforcement. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "article of fur" refers to furskins or articles made from furskins. The term "conventional steel-jawed leghold trap" describes a device designed to capture animals by snapping closed on their limb. The term "customs laws of the United States" refers to laws enforced by the United States Customs Service. "Import" means to bring into the jurisdiction of the United States. The term "customs laws of the United States" refers to any law or regulation enforced by the United States Customs Service. "Import" means to bring into the jurisdiction of the United States. The term "interstate commerce" is defined in section 10 of title 18, United States Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary is authorized to create rules for implementing the Act, which will become effective one year after its enactment.
